dialogue.text: Well she's been away for three and a half years in New York and suddenly she just shows up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe, maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody travels seven hundred miles just see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: uh-uh What do you mean?  They grew up next to each other their entire lives.  Why shouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey don't look at me like that.  I don't know anymore than you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who said he even thought about that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I see it.  It has the appearance of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen kid...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  She's not his girl Joe and she knows that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is still single?  I mean there's plenty of single men in New York.  Why isn't she married by now?  Probably a hundred men has told her that she's foolish but, she's waiting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?  Hmmm?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, her faith is stronger than a rock.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: My worst times I think about her, you know, and I

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's like I know as long as she's waiting I'm right again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at how nice the day is.  What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  Nobody in my house better dare and challenge her faith.  You know and maybe strangers but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?  What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want-I want you to act like he's still alive.  I mean don't think I haven't seen the way that you've been since he invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But Kate...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But I won't have any of this nonsense because you know what happens?  If he doesn't come back I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Laugh, laugh at me but I will.  Because you know what happened when she came here?  When she came back she slept in his room, the memorial broke into pieces. Joe, look. Look at it. You got to believe with me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself. Just calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't do it all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself, alright?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, it was just last week that Detroit, some boy came back he had been away longer than Larry, you can read it for yourself. You above all people have got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright, alright, calm yourself okay?  Calm yourself. Wait, wait.  What do you mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, just keep believing okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait, what does that mean?  Me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do I got to hide?  Huh?  What the hell's the matter with you Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, nobody knows we're here except for Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are we to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right, aren't we darling? Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello? What? Ugh, wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] God, it sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: things that should matter dreadfully don't seem to matter at all when one's happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um terrible thing is one can't stay happy. Well, it's true. I mean, the whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mean that sacred and beautiful thing, love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean? That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth. What does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me. I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. You mustn't be serious, my dear one, that's what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable. Laugh at them. Be flippant. Laugh at all the sacred shibboleths. Flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if I laugh at everything I'm going to have to laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh, certainly you must. We're figures of fun, all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So how long is it going to last? This ludicrous, overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. The fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, well, shall we want that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we play it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what if happens if one of us is to die? Does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. Yes, he must with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's serious enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No, it isn't. Death's very laughable. A cunning little mystery. All done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run. Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's blow strumpets, blow-blow trumpets and squeakers and party as much as we can like small quite idiotic school children. Let's savor the delight of the moment. Come, kiss me darling, before worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do, see? As long-you can paint yourself bright green all over and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you, dear. The same applies to you. Except that if I ever so much as catch you looking at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles. That was his name. Charles. He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible little thing. I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did. You threw it out the window and into the Grand Canal. I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your-your curling iron burnt a hole in my dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I burnt a hole in my comb too, and all the towels in the bathroom. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah. And that was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling on the floor and biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. Oh man. Couldn't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I will never forget his face. Ooh-rah [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my God, look at that. Huh-oh, how many carats is that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. [LAUGHTER]. Dude, I don't know. It's- Probably. It's huge. I don't even know how to like wear it. My hand is like going down like really low. I can't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like eighteen? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I- Yeah, it's-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So how did he do it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, man. So I was--okay, so we went to go see this show on Broadway, right? And it was The wed- the wed- The Lousy Chaperone. Have you seen that one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, The Lousy Chaperone. [LAUGHTER] Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right. Right. Right. So, and there's like a whole like wedding scene in it. All right, not the--Drowsy, Drowsy [LAUGHTER] --not the Lousy. [LAUGHTER]. Um - So Drowsy. So I go to see this Drowsy Chaperone. And uh-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Uh- Drowsy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: at the end of the performance, you know, like we're all clapping and stuff. And all of a sudden I look over and

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Joe's gone. -where did he go, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh. Oh-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I'm like oh, he went to the- -the bathroom, but he didn't tell me, I didn't even notice him leaving. And all of a sudden, I swear to God, I'm sitting there and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he comes up onstage-- And the entire cast everyone just like

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: oh-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: goes up there and everyone's clapping and he's standing there and they put a spotlight on him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I'm like freaking out. I'm like what the hell's going on, you know. I don't know what's going on. And so he's like standing there and then all of a sudden they give him a microphone-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and he just starts doing like this little spiel about me and like

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he asked me to marry him, like- onstage. I was like, I couldn't believe--and I had to walk up there and I was, like I think I tripped or something.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wha- What'd you say? You said yes, right? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I said yes, but I, yeah, I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know- it just like took me, took me by surprise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He scored points.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you get a standing ovation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah. Everyone--yeah. And people--friends of ours were in the audience, I didn't know about, like family members.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. It was great.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you serious?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was--I cried,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you deserve to cry. I mean, tears of happiness.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like a loser, I cried.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, I don't know, I--it's so weird to think I'm marrying somebody 'cause I feel so young, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So where- where- where is this--have you talked about where it's going to be?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No plans. or any- and probably

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like I think I want to get married--I want to have two weddings. One here, then one in Europe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hawaii? No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. Hawaii's for honeymoons. But uh--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh. Like Paris? On the Eiffel Tower?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, maybe. I don't know. I've been there so many times. I think it's--we're going to get married in Spain and then we're going to get married here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He's rich enough. Maybe you can rent out the Eiffel Tower for your--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's awesome. [LAUGHTER] Marriage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I'm so excited. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?  Maybe we ought to talk to him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean. He couldn't have seen it. I was the first one up, he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four in the morning.  I heard a crack and I looked out and he was standing right there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what was he doing out at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. But after it cracked he ran back into the house and he cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured the best thing to do was leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear it right through the floor.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, what was he doing out there anyway?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Starting to dream about him again.  He's walking around at night again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like he did after he died, you know?  What, what, what's the meaning of this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I know one thing mom, we made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  That kind of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know that too.  Why we both go on letting him think that we both believe with him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you going to do?  You want to argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I don't want to argue with him but, it's time that he realizes that nobody believes Larry's coming back anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he walk around and dream at him at night.  Walk around.  Why shouldn't he walk around?  Why shouldn't he dream of him, walk around at night waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say flat out that we don't have anymore hope?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How are you going to prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Larry's been gone for three years.  For god sakes no one comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you maybe, to me, but not to your father.  I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he still thinks he's alive still.  I mean you could talk yourself blue in the face and there's no body and there's no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen mom, just, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  It's his god damned newspapers is what it is.  Now every month there's a new boy comes home and Larry's going to be the next one.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright. Alright. Alright just listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I have an idea but I don't know.  What's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's your business Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  I mean, you're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So then it's alright.  I'll go ahead with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, you got to make sure your dad's not going--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh see then it's just not my business. God you infuriate me sometimes.  Isn't my business too if dad throws a fit?  Huh?  God you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm just saying--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know I ignore what I got to ignore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not...she's Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view he is still alive and if you try and take her that's just not fair.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something I want I have to pull back

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And-And-And if you go on from there if you know already to go on from there, then you can.  But I'm telling you something that I don't know where to go.  You got it?  I mean, do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because other people will suffer.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My whole entire, bloody life time and time again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There is nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well to hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what if she doesn't marry you huh?  What if she feels the same way your father does?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I guess that's the end of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.  I'll find out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with dad right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, you never had seen many, many women.  You know?  I mean...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what?  I'm just not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's a good answer but, it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you left to go to the war and it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just...that's just the way it is.  That's how I feel.  You know these years when I think of someone I want to marry I think of Annie.  What do you want a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. And you go off and marry that girl and you're just pronouncing him dead and what's going to happen to him?  I don't know.  Do you?  I mean, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, just give it some thought okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought and I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll marry her somewhere else.  Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long.  A good sucker and I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're just going to leave the business?  You have a business here.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it an hour out of the day.  If I have to grub for money all day long at least at evening I want it beautiful.  I want a family.  I want a wife.  I want some kids.  I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now Annie is in the middle of all that.  Where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.  You can leave this business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you can't talk like that you hear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean what the hell have we worked for then?  I mean, it's all for you Chris.  The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Just you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you don't talk like that you hear?  You don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look at this, goose bumps.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what'd you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I said.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR.  Somebody sold you a bill of goods that this wonderful event is going to take place on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not the only one.  Look at these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure.  They're all told the same story.  It's what keeps us coming back for more; keeps us excited; keeps us thinking that life is going to start any minute now if we could just find the right spot; get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm sorry, but it's still just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Don't take this the wrong way, but are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Goddamn it, Augie, don't ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that.  You always ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas about what this evening is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  We come down here.  The grunions arrive.  They do their little fish business.  We go ooh, ah, look at the fish.  They go home.  We go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, we are not going to see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We never do, do we?  Have we ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we've tried.  That's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll see them this year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, we won't.  It's pointless.  It's like waiting up to see Santa Claus.  I feel as though my entire life is going to be spent standing on the beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for the fish to show up.  And the fish won't show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't have any idea what I'm saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, of course, not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it.  I always do.  I keep thinking this time will be the time, but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish; nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been trying to work this backwards, but I can't seem to pinpoint the moment when we took a turn for the worse.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You were fine during the phone call from Marge.  Dinner was okay.  Doing the dishes was no problem.  Let's see, I took a shower.  Uh, you watched the news.  You said the grunions are running tonight.  I said great, let's go.  I feel lucky tonight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh,okay.  So I'm putting on my jacket; putting out the animals;

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first time we came to see it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: uh, taking the car out of the gara- out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was about four years ago, right after we got married.  We thought I was pregnant and we had a bottle of champagne but no glasses.  You asked me to dance.  So we took off our shoes and you popped the cork.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And while we were dancing, you said the softest, most intimate things to me, right into my ear so that I could feel them as much as hear them.  And I remember thinking this is it.  At last, at last I'm as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, I've got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dancing barefoot in the sand; drinking champagne from the bottle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was in the car, right?  Driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker?  You said let's get some champagne and I said times a wasting or something like that.  Right?  That's it, right?  You want this to be like the other time.  That's it.  Of course.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember some things.  I'd rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure.  Okay.  Alright.  I've got it.  Listen do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want to get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, you want me to breathe in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A new carpet?  A poodle?  An ice cream?  A back rub?  A suicide pact?  What?  What, Carla?  What the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want something to turn out the way it's supposed to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race.  You think this is what I had in mind?  You think that when I proposed, I had this great fantasy going that four years down the line, we'd come to the beach and yell at each other over fish?  No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I'm just like you.  I thought it was going to be all peaches and roses and wind in our hair and sand in our toes and the fish will always come and the bills will always pay themselves.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And we'll have three fat rosy kids and ha, ha, ha, baby, the joke's on us, 'cause you know what you get, Carla?  You know what you get?  This.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This what?  What is this?  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, right, sure.  This is standing on the beach.   This is waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But this isn't anything like I thought anything would be like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know, me neither.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is just this.  I mean, it includes a lot and everything, but it's just not, you know, something else.  Do you have any idea what I'm trying to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are, Augie.  Really, I do.  I know you meant for this to be special and nice and it's the full moon and the sand and everything.  But I just couldn't help thinking about being somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with somebody else, too, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know.  But still.  I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, whatever I'm doing, I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well don't be ridiculous.  Don't you know that?  You're the one who probably wishes you were with somebody else; somebody who knew how to enjoy herself and didn't take everything so hard.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually, now that you mention it, no.  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay, fine.  So we're in the wrong spot, but we're with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  It seemed like a good spot to me.  I mean, look at the view you've got of the moon from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I noticed that.  Looks pretty on the water, doesn't it?  Big ol' white moon.  I'm sorry, Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.  If we're very quiet, the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody knows we're here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll be alright, darling.  Whatever happens, aren't we?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello.  Hello.  What?  Wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ahh.  It sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What shall we do if they suddenly walk in on us?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With the most perfect poise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Certainly I shall probably do a court curtsy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Things that ought to matter dreadfully don't matter at all when one's happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is so horrible is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't say that, my darling.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true the whole business is very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Meaning that sacred and beautiful thing love.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean?  That's what I asked myself in my ceaseless quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mustn't be serious, my darling.  It's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Laugh at them, be flippant, laugh at everything, all their sacred shibboleths

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If I must laugh at everything, I must laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly you must.  We are figures of fun alright.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, how long will it last, this ludicrous, over-bearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We always want to bicker and fight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No that fire will fade long with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear shall we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It all depends on how well we've played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What happens if one of us dies?  Does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  Yes.  with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no it isn't.  Death is very laughable such a cunning little mystery.  All done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run.  Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party as much as we can like small quite idiotic little school children.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's savor the delight of the moment.  Come and kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't mind what you do, see. you can paint yourself green all over

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and dance naked in the place Place Vendome and rush away with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you, dear.  The same applies to you except that if I catch you so much as looking at another woman, I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you remember that awful scene in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one where you bought that little painted wooden snake and put it on my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, Charles.  That was his name.  Charles he did wriggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible thing.  I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I know you did.  You threw him out of the window into the Grand Canal.  I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your curling irons burnt holes in my dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It burnt my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, we were much younger then.  That was a rouser wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You didn't hit me- I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then the manager came in and found us rolling about on the floor biting and scratching like panthers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I shall never forget his face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How ridiculous.  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It's going out of style isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's so lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  But I'm not going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well your mother has much as told me to leave.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you saw that! And you.  You've been-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sort of embarrassed soon as I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well the plan was to kind of sneak up on you over a period of a week or so.  But uh- they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I figured they would- your mother at least.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, from her point of view why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, would you want to?  I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you!

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I- I -I have no imagination, that's all I know what to say, I-I'm embarrassing you. I I didn't want to tell you here.  I wanted it to be some place different, some place where we could be new to each other you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel it's wrong here, don't you- this yard, this chair?  I want you to be ready for me Annie.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready for a long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then, he's gone forever-you're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, why didn't you say something to me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I was waiting for you!  I mean I didn't-until then you hadn't written and when you write- when you wrote what did you say?  I mean you sure can be ambiguous Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Ann. Give me a-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh God- I kissed Annie! I can't believe I kissed Annie!  How long I've wanted to do this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait so long?  All this time I've been wondering if I was a fool for thinking of you!

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that, you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  Chris, what's the matter?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's Let's drive someplace.  I- I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it, your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?  Even in your letters, there is something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's- It's mixed up with so many other things, I-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Remember when I was overseas?  I was in command of the company.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: how many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh gee.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Takes a little time to toss something like that off you know because they weren't just men-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: for instance, there's this one time.  It had been raining for several days.  And this kid came up to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks. you know, He just put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that- that's not a big thing, but it's just the kind of guys I had. They didn't die. They- They killed themselves for each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean that exactly that-a little more selfish and they would have still been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I got an ideal, watching them all go down.  Everything was being destroyed see and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: but it seemed to me that something new was being created at the same time, a kind of responsibility, man for man.  Do you understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And to show that-to-to bring that back onto the earth again like a- like a monument.  And everyone would have it standing behind them and- and it would make a difference for them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then I went home and it was incredible.  It had no meaning here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was all like some kind of bus accident to them.  I went back to work with my dad, in that whole rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt what you said- ashamed somehow-because nobody had changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a whole lot of guys. and

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It felt wrong to be alive-to open that bank-book; to buy that new car; to look at that new refrigerator.  I mean, you can take those things out of the war, but if you drive that car, you have to know that that comes from the love that a man has for a man.  And you've got to be a little bit better than that!

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And if you're not, then it's all just loot and it's got blood on it, and I don't want any of it!  And, I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you can't feel like that anymore Chris, you hear me?  I mean everything that you have, you deserve.  And that includes me.  And your father?  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air, you should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie.  Annie, I am going to make you a fortune!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What would I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so?  What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I was just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not. It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR, somebody sold you a bill of goods that this wonderful event is going to occur on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not the only one, look at all these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, they are all told the same thing.  They are all told that you know.  Gets them excited and they can't wait and that if they just get in on the right spot, than you than maybe life will start

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am sorry.  It's just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you a question?  Now don't be upset, are you having a period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God damn it, Augie.  Why do you always ask things like that?  It's so insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just had a different idea of what this evening is going to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  We come down here.  The grunion arrives and they do their little fish thing.  And we say, Oh, wow.  Look at the little fish.  They go home, we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake Augie, grow up we are not going to see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We never do.  Have we ever?  We never have.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We miss them twice, it's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we tried, that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well We will see them this year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, we won't.  Augie it's like waiting for Santa Claus to come.  I feel like I am going to spend my entire life standing on the beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasp expectantly in front of me waiting for the fish to show up and the fish will not show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did, I do want to see it.  I always want to see it, Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish, it's nothing to get traumatize over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, I been trying to work this backwards but I can't seem to pinpoint a moment when we took a turn for the worst here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: When you are on the phone with Marge, everything was fine.  Dinner was okay.  Doing the dishes was no problem. Let's see, I took a shower and you were watching the news and you said the grunions are running tonight and I said, great, let's go I am feeling lucky.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right, so I am putting on my jacket and putting up the animals and pulling the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, do you remember the first time we came to see it?  It was about four years ago right after we got married and we thought I was pregnant.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We had a bottle of champagne but no glasses and you ask me to dance so we took off our shoes and while we were dancing, you said the most intimate things right in my ears so I could feel them as much as hear them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I remember thinking, Finally, finally.  I am as happy as I am supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dancing barefoot in the sand, drinking champagne from the bottle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was in the car, right?  When we were passing Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said, Let's get some champagne.  And I said time wasting or something like that.  Right? of course.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I rather not remember some things.  I rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, all right I got it.  You wanted it to be like the other time, okay no problem. Listen, You want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want me to go get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, you want me to whisper in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? What You want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No no.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation? A new carpet, a poodle?  A bag of ice cream, a suicide pack, what what Carla?  What the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want something to turn out the way it is suppose to turn out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What.  Welcome to the human race.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is what I had in mind?  You think that when I propose I had this great fantasy going that four years down the road, we will end up on a beach arguing over fish. You think that I knew that there would be times when you will look at me like I am used Kleenex?  Or that I will look at you and think, holy hell what's the next flight to Alaska.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no I was just like you, I thought it will be all peaches and roses and- and sand in our toes and wind in our hair and the fish will always come. And the bills will always magically pay themselves and we will have three fat rosy kids and we will be, HAHA baby the joke is on us.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because you know what Carla?  You know what you get?  This.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This what?  What is this?  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure, this is standing.  This is waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But this isn't anything like I thought it would be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know me either.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean it is just this , I mean it includes a lot and everything and you know it's the sand and it's the full moon and I just-I am sorry but I couldn't help wishing I was somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you are with somebody else too?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know, but.  I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake Augie, wherever I am I always wanted to be with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Whatever I am doing, I wanted to be with you.  I mean you are probably the one who wishes you were with somebody else, somebody who didn't take everything so hard and who knows how to enjoy herself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually, now that you mention it.  No, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Good.  So maybe we are on the wrong spot but we are with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  Seems like a pretty good spot to me I mean look at the view of the moon you got from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did notice that.  It does look really beautiful on the water.  The gold white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, look what we have got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you bought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, it's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well than we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you still cold?  You still want to go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I am beginning to think that maybe this is the spot after all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh, If we're very quiet, the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did you invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and a half years.  Why all of the sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe.  Maybe she just wanted to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What did you mean? He lived next door to the girl all of his life, why wouldn't he want to see her again? Don't look at me like that, he didn't tell me any more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he is even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, listen, Kate, just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's . . . Then why is she still single.  New York is full of men, why isn't she married?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know - she's faithful as a rock and my worst moments I think of her waiting and I know again that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look.  It's a nice day.  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in her- this house dares shake her faith.  Strangers might, but not his father, and not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to pretend like he's coming back!

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But, Kate...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, then I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Laugh.  Laugh at me, but what happens the night that she goes to sleep in his bed, and his memorial breaks in pieces?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Only last week, another boy turned up in Detroit, been missing longer than Larry, you read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right.  Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You above all, have got to believe, Joe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me, above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to believe. You've got to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean me above all?  Look at you.  You're shaking!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it!

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?  Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?  I was the first one up.  He was still in bed.  How could he have seen it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, like, four o'clock this morning.  I heard a crack, and I woke up, and I looked out the window and he was standing right there when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, but after it broke he ran back inside and started crying in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured it was best to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear him right through the floor in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out there at that hour?  He's getting just like after Larry died, walking around at night.  He dreams.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it, but you know one thing Mom, we made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  It's the kind of thing that pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know it.  So why do we go on letting him think that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him.  But it's time he knows that nobody else thinks that Larry's alive anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why should he dream about him, walking around looking for him at night?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore, that we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We have to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: how are you gonna prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For Gods sake!  Three years!  Nobody comes back after three years.  That's insane!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.  Now you can talk yourself until you're blue in the face, Chris, but there's no body and there's no grave.  So where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is the God damn newspapers.  I mean every every week a kid turns up, missing like longer than Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right, mom.  Just listen.  You know why I invited Annie her, don't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I have an idea.  But what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to make- to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's okay then?  I should just go ahead and do it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, so it isn't just my business?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You infuriate me sometimes.  Do you know that?  God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Isn't it your business, too, if dad -- if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it?  I mean, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore.  I mean, the girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She is not Larry's girl!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view he's not dead and she's still his girl.  Now, you can go on from there if you know where to go, Chris, but I don't know.  So what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but everytime I reach out for something I- that I want, I have to pull back because I might hurt somebody else.  My whole bloody life; time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you're a considerate fella, there's nothing wrong in that

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this taken care of first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what if she feels like your father?  And how do you know she will marry you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if that's the case, then that's the end of it.  But from her letters it sounds like she has forgotten him.  I'll find out.  And then we'll thrash it out with dad, all right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, the trouble is you never saw enough women.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's a good reason.  But that doesn't mean anything at all.  I mean, you haven't seen her in five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know her best, all right?  I don't know.  I grew up next to her.  When I think of somebody for my wife these days, I think of Annie.  What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I don't want a -- look, your father thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl and you're pronouncing him dead.  Now, what's going to happen to your father; do you know?  Because, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then, mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  I hoped that if I'd waited, dad would have forgotten about it by now.  And we could have like a normal wedding and everybody happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if that can't happen, I'll just have to get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll go get married and live someplace else.  I don't know, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have been a good son for too long.  A good sucker.  I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  You mean?  Tell me something, you mean that you would leave the business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But don't think like that.  Because what the hell did we work for, Chris?  I mean, this whole thing, it's all for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that, mom.  Just, you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think that way.  Do you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is it them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Freda is the only one who knows we are here.  She wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.  What are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We are okay, aren't we darling?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello?  Hello?  I'm sorry, what's that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Wrong number. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What shall we do if they suddenly walk in on us.[LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We'll behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With perfect poise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think I shall do a curtsy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's strange; things that ought to matter dreadfully, they just don't matter at all when one's happy.  Do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  The pity is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true.  I think the whole thing's a cruel joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  This beautiful and sacred thing - love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  Meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well what does it all mean?  That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God, what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm being serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh darling, you mustn't be serious.  It's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All of those futile moralists who make life unbearable.  You have to laugh at them, be flippant.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, flippancy brings out the acid in their darned, light and sweetness.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you know if I laugh at everything then I must laugh at us, too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh of course.  We are figures of fun.  All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long with it last, this ludicrous overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh no.  That fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, should we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well it depends on how well we've played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What happens if one of us dies?  Does the other one still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  Yes with all of his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. no.  Death is a very laughable thing.  It's a cunning little mystery, it's all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think you are talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So is everyone, in the long run.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial, and just pity those poor philosophers, huh?  Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party for as long as we can, you know, like small, idiotic school children.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Come and kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh See, I don't care what you do, see.  You can paint yourself green and run naked through the Place Vendome and run off with all of the men of the world.  I shan't say a word, just as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw.  Thank you, darling.  The same applies to you too, except that if you so much as look at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one where you put that tiny painted wooden snake in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles, that was his name.  He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was a terrible thing.  I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did.  You threw him out the window into the Grand Canal.  I'll never forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But the worst one was in Cannes when your curling irons burnt a hole in my new dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh And it burnt my comb, too, and all of those towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That was the first time you hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I did not hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in, he found us rolling about the floor, biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] I'll never forget his face. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However I believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hi. Um-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hi, can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It seems that uh- my-my bag didn't make it out on the carousel.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, did you check? Did you make sure as it went around the second time that it-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, it's gone around like you know twenty times. It's been about a half hour.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. Well, um- the f.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Actually I'm looking here at the information, the flight that you were on we had some trouble with some of the baggage, it looks like a few peoples' bags didn't make it through. Um, so-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. So what-what do I have to get you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you can fill out this paperwork um- and if for some reason it shows up, we can bring it to you, but-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For some reason, so you think it won't show up?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, sometimes it's just late baggage or misplaced baggage and it comes out but it seems to be here and just I'm reading off of this that

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh- it didn't make it into the second plane so it looks like there - they don't actually know what happened to it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? What? How does that happen?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, well, sometimes there is just difficulties with loading on to the plane. Uh- There can be a theft or uh- some sort of you know mishap with a cart or something.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I really - I really need that bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I- I- I understand, but um.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: there are- I have important things in that bag. I've got

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean -- I've been away for a while and- and now I've- I've gifts for- for you know friends and family I mean, I got stuff in the there

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's worth a lot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I understand that. Um- So I'm going to put down here that you looking for your baggage, but we actually can't, uh this bag is likely not going to show up so what we're going to do-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Not going to show - well isn't like - wouldn't it just be at the airport, that, like, if it didn't get on the other plane

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: can they check there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sometimes it gets stolen, sometimes it gets misplaced on another plane and

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: on another-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: they - they, it gets shipped to somewhere else and then it's stuck somewhere and then we have no way of tracking that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So we'll- what we'll do

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But we have the tags on. I mean like it wouldn't you know, if it got stuck somewhere it's like well this is nobodies bag I mean maybe you know look on the tag and

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: see where it came from originally. I mean it seems like-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right. Like I said sometimes a theft and things happen like that but we are willing to reim-reimburse you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Theft?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, so.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Theft? Don't you know like all these people that are work - you keep like an eye on them, how can they get away with-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We have very tight security but we -uh- there are times when we just can't uh make sure there aren't absolutely no human error, you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry there is no guarantee on baggage.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is unbelievable. I've got

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you don't realize the stuff that I've got in that - I really need to get the suitcase okay

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I understand, so-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so if it's back there or something, if there is something you can do

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I need you to tell me because I really need to get the bag, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: all right, We've already checked back here for your baggage

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and we will continue to look for it and because your paper-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You've already checked? Can you check again? [garbage]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've already looked, thank you very much and because we've filled out paperwork if it shows up we will send it to you but otherwise what we can do is reimburse you for fifty dollar.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Fifty- fifty dollars? Come on you have got to be joking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's- it's just sort of help with the fact uh that you lost some of your possessions and we rather do that than-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh, yea, lost some of my possessions, yes, so if I lost maybe a shoe that was in the suitcase and like a carry-on

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: that might be like fifty dollars okay, but this - I- [garbage] I had like thousands of dollars worth of stuff in that suitcase.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The airline can't afford to give you everything that is in that suitcase. and so-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The a- what? Talking about a core they can't afford it? I mean-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well because lots of people get their baggage lost and we don't want to have false claims or anything like that so we have

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: we can give you fifty dollar to sort of make up for it, to compensate, and we can definitely let you know if it shows up but likely, more than likely-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean you're not helping me here. What do I have to do here? Do I need to sue the airline company is that what I should do

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: because this is ridiculous?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry. I don't- I-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't believe you should sue the airline company but we do have a policy uh- in which we can reimburse you and that's all we can do and I'm sorry I've done everything I can-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. I'm sick- I'm sick of this all right. I'm sick of you and keep your fifty dollar.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's other people waiting-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uhm, I don't know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So how you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know what I'm going to do about this; I mean

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have got to get a job, you know? Like-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've been doing a lot of work for it, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, yea you know, I get my resumes and I mean I-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right, so the fact you doing the best that you can is -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I go out all the places I can, every place that'll give an interview you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you know you shouldn't give yourself a hard time for that, it's the best you can.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But it's been so long, like what - what am I - what am I waiting -- I should probably just do something else, or

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, but you care about what you do, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, I mean why - why

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, but it's - it's almost like it's not worth it you know, if I'm going to waste to have my life like trying to get a job, I mean once I actually do get the job it's like oh, retirement or something. I don't know, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I understand that it's so frustrating but I know that you're here because you really want it you know and, and uh

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, and that's what I begin to question after a while is maybe I just don't want it, maybe it's not even worth it, you know, like

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't even know if it's going to be worth it because I can't break myself in, you know like I can't - can't even get a foot in the door you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean you're still here you've tried for this long so I think that says something all in itself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, it says I'm stupid enough to be trying this long and not move on somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are persistence. I mean that's important. that's

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, I can't- I can't be persistent forever, you know, you can't not have a job forever, you know, I've got- I've got to do something, I've got to make money and get food on the table.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you're talented so keep that in mind, you know, you shouldn't give yourself too hard of a time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, maybe I'm not, you know. I don't have a job. Maybe - maybe I'm not as good as-as I thought I was and

dialogue.speaker: M
