dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know that too.  Why we both go on letting him think that we both believe with him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you going to do?  You want to argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I don't want to argue with him but, it's time that he realizes that nobody believes Larry's coming back anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he walk around and dream at him at night.  Walk around.  Why shouldn't he walk around?  Why shouldn't he dream of him, walk around at night waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say flat out that we don't have anymore hope?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How are you going to prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Larry's been gone for three years.  For god sakes no one comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you maybe, to me, but not to your father.  I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he still thinks he's alive still.  I mean you could talk yourself blue in the face and there's no body and there's no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen mom, just, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  It's his god damned newspapers is what it is.  Now every month there's a new boy comes home and Larry's going to be the next one.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright. Alright. Alright just listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I have an idea but I don't know.  What's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's your business Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  I mean, you're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So then it's alright.  I'll go ahead with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, you got to make sure your dad's not going--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh see then it's just not my business. God you infuriate me sometimes.  Isn't my business too if dad throws a fit?  Huh?  God you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm just saying--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know I ignore what I got to ignore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not...she's Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view he is still alive and if you try and take her that's just not fair.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something I want I have to pull back

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And-And-And if you go on from there if you know already to go on from there, then you can.  But I'm telling you something that I don't know where to go.  You got it?  I mean, do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because other people will suffer.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My whole entire, bloody life time and time again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There is nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well to hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what if she doesn't marry you huh?  What if she feels the same way your father does?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I guess that's the end of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.  I'll find out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with dad right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, you never had seen many, many women.  You know?  I mean...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what?  I'm just not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's a good answer but, it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you left to go to the war and it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just...that's just the way it is.  That's how I feel.  You know these years when I think of someone I want to marry I think of Annie.  What do you want a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. And you go off and marry that girl and you're just pronouncing him dead and what's going to happen to him?  I don't know.  Do you?  I mean, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, just give it some thought okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought and I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll marry her somewhere else.  Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long.  A good sucker and I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're just going to leave the business?  You have a business here.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it an hour out of the day.  If I have to grub for money all day long at least at evening I want it beautiful.  I want a family.  I want a wife.  I want some kids.  I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now Annie is in the middle of all that.  Where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.  You can leave this business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you can't talk like that you hear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean what the hell have we worked for then?  I mean, it's all for you Chris.  The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Just you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you don't talk like that you hear?  You don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.  It's a good thing.  You know, it's lovely here and the air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, not sorry, but I'm not going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You saw that and then you've been kind of--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so.  But they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would, your mother, anyway.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From her point of view, why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well wouldn't you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have no imagination.  That's all I know to tell you.  I'm embarrassing you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I wanted someplace we'd never been; someplace where we'd be brand new to each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is wrong, don't you; this yard, this chair?  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever?  You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  'Til then, you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, give me a kiss.  Give me a -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.  I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've waited to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit around and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it, Chris?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it, Chris?  Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what's wrong.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I suppose there has been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, gees.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a little time to toss that off because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time it'd been raining several days.  And this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks; put them in my pocket.  That's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I got this idea watching them go down, everything was being destroyed, see?  But, to me, it seemed there was one new thing that was made,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: a kind of responsibility.  Man for man.  You understand me?  And then I went home and it was incredible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them was some sort of bus accident.  Then I went to work for dad and that whole rat race again.  I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: because nobody was changed.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive;

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to open that bank book; to drive the new car; to see the new refrigerator.  I mean, you can take these things out of a war, but when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have to be a little better because of that.  Otherwise, we have is really loot and there's blood on it.  I don't want to take any of it.  I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way anymore, Chris.  Because you have a right to everything you have, everything, Chris; to me, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And your money, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  You should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie, I'm going to make you a fortune.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, man, I just -- I don't know what to do.  I don't know what to do.  It's like every job, you know, I go to; every job I apply to,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: it's just like nobody- nobody wants to hire me. It's been years, I mean, do you understand, years?  Like, I'm -- you know what I mean, it's like I've been collecting unemployment for so long now, it's just like I just -- I can't take it.  I don't know what to do.  I mean, I'm just like losing my mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well there has to be something you haven't tried.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I'm not kidding.  I've tried everything.  Like I've gone to every business and local, you know,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: local business in- in the area and I can't- I can't get anything.  Like, nobody -

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about like a temp agency?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Have you gone, like, signed up with a temp agency?  Maybe they can help.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: there's just like no jobs available.  I mean, it's just like, God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I tried that.  And there was like, yeah, like I did like one thing once.  But, like, that's not -- it doesn't last very long.  And it's not enough to live on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right, but you have -- I mean, you have to keep on them.  You have to keep calling and reminding them that you're still looking and

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, you have to be really aggressive about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I do.  I do.  You don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I- You don't understand. I don't have a job.  All- My job is to look for a job.  I don't do anything else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But, like, it's been years now and I just can't seem to get anything that really fits.  It's just it -- I -- it drives me absolutely insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, if it's that bad, maybe you're gonna have to take something that doesn't really fit, you know.  Like maybe you'll have to do something else for a while.  Find a new field, new skill.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no.  I can't- I can't do that.  I can't, I- because if I'm not- if I'm not- if I'm not doing something that I love, then I can't -- I can't- I mean it's- what's the point?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then you're choosing to be unemployed, really.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not choosing. I'm not-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you're not willing to try and work with it and find something and, you know, I mean, there are things you could do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, but I'm try- but like all the things that I-it's like I apply to all these places and none of them

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -- I mean, I don't understand.  It's like -- I mean, I feel like I'm qualified enough.  I just don't understand.  Like, I mean, it's just like a matter of circumstance, but it's been three years, you know, three years.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well maybe, you know, your luck it is just down and the market for your particular field is down and maybe you just need to look into doing something else for a while.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is stupid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, I'm not saying that you should, you know--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what, this is your fault.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's your fault 'cause -cause you always told me to- to do this and I did that instead.  And I didn't take your advice and - and- but you sort of were like were telling--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's my fault 'cause you didn't do what I told you to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that sounds like your fault.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You didn't do what I told you to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's 'cause you always tell me to do the wrong thing.  And I thought this time it was -- I was gonna be right by going with the opposite thing. So it's your fault because

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -because you were always wrong and-and-and this time you were right. And-and I didn't -- yeah, that's why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's amazing logic that you managed to turn that around and make it my fault.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, it makes sense, doesn't it, hmm?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think maybe you can't get employed because you aren't willing to take responsibility for your own actions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's not true.  I take responsibility for my own actions.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?  Whose fault is it you don't have a job?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yours.  I don't--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You see what you just did there, though?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I had- No, I don't.  I'm sorry.  I just totally screwed this one up.  You can stop it I guess.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know it went out of style didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.  It's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not sorry, no but I'm not staying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You saw that and you- you've been kind of-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so but they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would, your mother anyway.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From her point of view why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wouldn't you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have no imagination that's all I know to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you.  I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: wanted some place we'd never been, a place where we'd be brand new to each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is wrong, this chair, this yard.  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever.  You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  Till then you never wrote and then when you did what did you say.  I mean you sure can be ambiguous you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Ann.  Give me a-God I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it Chris?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive some place.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  What is it Chris, your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then what's wrong?  Even in your letters there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I suppose I have been but it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I put them in my pocket. that's only a little thing but these are the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There was no meaning in it here.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: because nobody was changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I felt wrong to be alive, to open the new bank book, to drive the new car, to see the new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean you can take those things out of war but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've got to be a little better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F

What I can do for you right now is what I'm telling you is that I can do- I can give you a hundred dollars back and then you'll have to fill out a complaint form and then you'll get -- there'll be some investigation. Some men will show up at your house and go through your things.

dialogue.text: Yeah.  That's fine.  I just -- that's fine. Yeah, I mean, it doesn't make any difference to me.  I mean, it's not like it's going to cost my job or anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right. Um, Thanks for asking, though. I mean, you sound nice, you know.

dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.text: He's getting just like after he died.  What's the meaning in that?

dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back.  And I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry's alive anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he dream of him?  Walk the nights waiting for him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do we contradict him?  Do we say straight out that we have no hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years, now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've gotta say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How are you going to prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.  You can talk yourself blue in the face, but there's no body and no grave, so where are you?

dialogue.text: You know it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Well, then you know it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of view, he's not dead.  And you have no right to take his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go. But I'm telling you I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something I want, I have to pull back because other people will suffer.  My whole bloody life, time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.text: How do you know she'll marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's the end of it.  From her letters, I think she's forgotten him.  We'll find out.  Then we'll thrash it out with dad. Right, mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is, you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.text: So what?  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's a good answer, but it don't answer anything.  He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl, you're pronouncing him dead.  Now what happens to your father?  Do you know?  Because I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright, then, mom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright, then, mom.  Did we skip something?  No.  Alright, then, mom.

dialogue.text: Yes we did. Do you want to keep going?

dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.text: father forgot about Larry, we'd have a regular wedding and everything happy.  If I can't get that here, then I'll have to get out.

dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.text: Must you be inspired?

dialogue.text: Yes.  I like getting an hour a day.  If I have to grub for money all day long, at least at evening, I want it beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want a family.  I want some kids.  I want to build something I can give myself to.  Annie's in the middle of that.  Now where do I find it?

dialogue.text: You don't want to think like that.

dialogue.text: Then you help me stay here.

dialogue.text: Alright.  But just don't think like that because what the hell did we work for?  That's all for you, Chris.  The whole shooting match is just for you.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But don't think that way, you hear me?

dialogue.text: I am thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.text: Yeah, I can see that.

dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.text: When I was seven, my- my grandmother died and I really- I don't know, I mean it was really hard to let go but the important thing is- is that you do let go and your realize that, you know, they- you know, they- this person had fun while they were- while they were here and, uh, you know, you work- you work through it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know it's just, I just, you know, I mean it just happened.  I just, like- I just keep expecting him to walk in, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm. Yeah.  Yeah.  I mean it's- it's hard.  It's hard.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I mean, you know, I mean it was I mean with that kind of condition,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I know. I know.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's sort of- it's almost better off to rest in peace than he is to live in pain.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know. But I'd rather have him here with me, you know. It's just not fair.  I mean he- he didn't get to do like anything. I mean he was-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It just doesn't seem fair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not fair but I mean that's, you know, the course of life is that, you know, you meet people and you lose them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're okay

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you for being here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I think- I think we should celebrate because I think that's what he would have wanted.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] You're probably right.  He probably would be pissed if we were all sitting around being upset about it. He'd want us to have a party.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And to drink in his honor. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's right.  That's right.  I mean he would want us to, you know, celebrate the life that he- that he lived and, you know, enjoy the rest of ours as much as we can.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing I can do for you.  Do you understand that?  Nothing.

dialogue.text: Ma'am you're going to have- you- look. You really- you really

dialogue.text: No.  No.  No. No. You have to help me.

I mean, you can take those things out of the war, but if you drive that car, you have to know that that comes from the love that a man has for a man.  And you've got to be a little bit better than that!

dialogue.text: Well,

dialogue.text: Oh, gee.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time, it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.  I put them in pocket.  It's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: You still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: First of all your mother so much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you saw the way that she acted and then well, I mean, you, you were acting kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know, embarrassed of her since I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well the trouble is I was planning on sneaking up on you over a week or so and they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know they would, especially your mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what other reason, from her point of view, would I be coming here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, would you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, that's the reason why I asked you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie.  I love you.  I love you a great deal.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess that's why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't...I have no imagination that's the only way I know how to tell it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you.  I didn't want to tell you this here.  I wanted to drive someplace brand new where we'd be brand new to each other.  It feels wrong here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This yard and this chair.  I don't want to win you from anything, I want you to be ready for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I've been ready for a long, long time now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever, you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you Chris, I mean, till then you never wrote and then when you did what did you say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'd always be so ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss Ann, just give me...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh God.  Annie, I kissed Annie.  I kissed Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long, how long I've been waiting to do that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean,  Why did you wait all these years?  There I was sitting around and wondering if I was crazy for thinking about you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.  Hey, let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it?  Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, nothing, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me what's wrong.  I mean, even in your letters you seemed ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, yes I guess I've been ashamed but, it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  It wouldn't work like this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Takes a little while to toss that off cause they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time this...it had been raining several days and this one kid, he came up to me, he gave me his last pair of dry socks, put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's just a little thing but that's the kind of guys I had.  They didn't just die, they killed themselves for each other and I mean that exactly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A little more selfish and they'd still be here today.  And I got this idea watching them go down.  See everything was being destroyed but there was one new thing that was being created.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was a kind of responsibility, man for man.  You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And to show that and to bring that onto the earth again like some sort of monument standing right behind all of us and we could feel it and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then I came here and it was incredible.  There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them was a kind of bus accident.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I went to work with dad and that rat race again and I felt what you said, ashamed.  Somehow because nobody was changed at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It seemed to make a sucker out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive.  I felt wrong to have that new checkbook,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: open that new bank account, drive the new car and see the new refrigerator

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: cause you can take those things out of the war.  But you got to know, when you drive that car that it came out of the love that a man can have for a man and you got to be a little bit better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise what you have is loot and there's blood on it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want to take any of it and I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cause you must not feel that way again.  You hear me?  You can't.  You deserve everything you have Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: that includes me too, I mean and the money, you have right to that money.  Your father put planes up in the air, good planes and he deserves it, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [GARBAGE] Annie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie I'm going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What am I going to do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Buy some hats?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say? Maybe we ought to talk to him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What-how did he see it? I mean, I was the first one up. He was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um, about four this morning. Uh- I heard a crack and I looked out and I saw him standing there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. But after it cracked he went back in the house and he cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I uh-, I figured the best thing to do was to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard, huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear it right through the floor.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out there at that time? He was dreaming about him again. He's walking around at night again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Could he-he's acting just like he did after he died, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's the meaning in that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But I know one thing, mom. We've made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you mean? What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him. That kind of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry's not coming back and I know that too. Why do we go on letting him think that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What, you're going to argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I don't want to argue with him, but it's time that he realized that no one believes that Larry's coming back anymore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't tell him that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We got to tell him that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can't. It just won't work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, for God's sakes it's been three years. No one comes back after three years. It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They do come back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, but he doesn't know that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Three years has been a long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. Just- Sit down, mom. I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's those Goddamn newspapers, you know? I mean, it's like every day they come out with this new person that comes along. And the next one's going to be Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Just come on, sit down.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know-you know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I have an idea, but go on, tell me, what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come on, you know that's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it is. I mean, what do you want me to do? You're grown up; you know what's going on in your mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's all right. I'll just go ahead with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you better make sure your father's not- No- I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See, then it's not just my business. God, you have

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -Oh, you infuriate me sometimes. You know, it's not just my business too if dad throws a fit.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God. You have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, well I ignore what I got to ignore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And she-she's Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, she is not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, from your father's point of view she is. I mean, he's still alive. You've got no right to take her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you go on from that point, I don't know where you go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause listen, I'm telling you, I don't know where to go from there. Do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want from me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because other people will suffer. My whole entire life, time and time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fella and there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's nothing wrong with it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't ask Annie yet.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You didn't ask her yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you? I mean, what if she feels the same way as your father?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then I guess it's over then. But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll find out. But then after it's all over we'll thrash it out with dad, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, the trouble is you've never had enough women. No, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what? I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand why it has to be her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, you haven't seen her since the war. I mean, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It just is. I-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I grew up with her. Okay. All these years, when I think of someone I want to be my wife I think of Annie. What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. You go-go on and marry her, I mean, you're pronouncing her dead. And what's going to happen to your father, huh? I don't know. Do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. All right, then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, listen. Give it more thought, is all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I've given it three years of thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here then I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out. I'll marry her somewhere else. Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're crazy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a sucker too long. I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're what-you're going to leave the business? But you can't do that. What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business. The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. I like it an hour out of the day. If I have to grub for money all day long at least that evening I want it beautiful. I want a wife. I want a family. I want some kids. I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, Annie's in the middle of all that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'd leave that business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right, but you can't do that. You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We've worked all our lives for you. Only for you, Chris. The whole shootin' match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know, I know, just help me stay here, all right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm going to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You just can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's it going, babe?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey listen,eh- I've been wanting to talk to you. I have something to tell you. How's Amy doing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's doing fine. She just took her first steps today actually. I videotaped it for you so you can watch it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I really want to say that. Well I, so, you know, at the center department they called me in and I talked to-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah? What did they say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well umm- actually they--I was promoted.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, wow. That's great.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And Uh- Yeah. Uh- They're going to need um- more nurses on call for uh- to go overseas to help out with the war.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And uh - seeing as I was uh- promoted and head of the department now, and so- well, they asked me to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: when?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going- It's going to be probably in about three weeks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? You can't do that. Three weeks?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm leaving in three weeks, but-- Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, we're supposed to take a look at a house next week.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we can still do that

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't- No, I can't do this alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and uh--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amy's starting school in a month.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, but look, I have to take this. I mean, if I don't, I mean, I could get fired.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And we know you need-we need the money. We couldn't even- purchase a house if I didn't take this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what happened to my cousin. She went and she never came back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey, I'm going to come back. It's not like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But it- it is for a year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Babe, I'm sorry. But I don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know as much as -as much as me that I-I want to stay here with you and Amy so bad, but I can't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember the last time you went? You know how hard it was for me? Now we have a kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But you're so good with her. You know, she knows you better than she knows me 'cause I'm at work every day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Babe, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't leave your daughter alone like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But she has you. I mean, that's what you're there for. You're my right-hand man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't postpone it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Wait, you can write me and as you know, send me pictures.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if I can handle you going another year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know if I- if I could take it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I need you to be strong for me. 'Cause I can't be the only one that's strong right now, really, I--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't be that strong. A whole year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: me, oh my god.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But we can work, you know, we--you can write me and we could see pictures

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What if you don't come back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and if we survive, if we survive that then babe, you know you know we could survive any--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will come back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I supposed--oh, one out of five people aren't coming back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It doesn't look very good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can do it. I'm going to do it. And I'll be back safe and sound and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: we'll have all the money that we ever needed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And- And then I'll stop working and- I'll stay home with the baby.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want the money. I want-you here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: we'll get money, all right? You don't need the job, all right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If your life is going to be in danger and this family is going to be in danger we don't need the job. We'll find the money.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's all I ever knew how to do. I can't quit now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How are we supposed to tell Amy? How's she supposed to understand that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, we- we tell her mommy's going on va- on a trip for for- a while.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How is she going to feel the first year in school, no mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't do that to me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's hard enough already, Brian, I can't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not thinking about just me; I'm thinking about our child.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't expect this to happen. I never planned for this. Some things you just don't plan for, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, babe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Esmeralda, guess what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Guess who just got hitched?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up. Oh my God.  Really? Just like that?  You just asked the question and what...how did you ask?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This guy. Yeah.  Can you believe it? She said yes too. Yeah.  She said yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay we were at Chuck E. Cheese.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chuck E. Cheese?  Ah, man that is so lame.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you serious [GARBAGE] man?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Get the big pizza--and I put it in the pizza and she ate so [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh like that one movie.  What's that one movie I just saw? No.  Where she like swallows the...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: American Pie? Ah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: oh, I don't remember.  Everybody Says I Love You with Drew Barrymore...no you haven't seen it?  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  It sounds like a chick flick. Anyways so, she gets the ring and she goes,

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, man this is great.  I wouldn't miss this for anything.  I mean think about this.  I know you're not interested but just think about this for a minute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Out there someplace there's this huge mass of silver fish heading this way.  They don't know why.  We don't know why.  It wasn't a decision.  They didn't take a vote.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They're swimming right now as if that's the only thing that matters.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  Urgency that's pure urge.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They don't know what drives them.  They don't give it a name or ask question.  They just turn as one and start the swim that brings them here to this place

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: where we stand for massive celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, I'm giving myself goose bumps.  All my hairs are popping up.

dialogue.text: That's the wind.
