dialogue.text: Everyday since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, why didn't you call me or tell me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, until then you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  I mean, you sure can be ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Annie.  Give me a --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: oh, God I kissed Annie.  I kissed Annie. I can't How long have I waited to do that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait so long?  All this time I've sat around wondering if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Annie, we're gonna live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What's the matter?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Lets go for a ride.  I I- I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  Chris, what is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even in your letters there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's so mixed up with so many other things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember when I was overseas, I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It- It takes time to toss something like that off,I mean, because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, there was this time, and it had been raining for several days, and this kid came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks, just put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know it's it's just a little thing but that's just the kind of guys I had.  They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean that exactly, anymore selfish -- just a little bit more selfish and they would have been here today. And it gave me an idea as I was watching them all go down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Everything was being destroyed see, but I felt like something new was being created at the same time.  Like it kind of -- responsibility.  You know, man to man.  Do you understand what I'm saying?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And and to see that again, to to bring that back on the earth again, like- like a monument that that would stand behind these men and and and it would make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was and then I went home.  And it was incredible.  It didn't have any meaning there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, the whole thing was like some kind of bus accident to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So I went back to work for my dad and that whole rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I felt what you said, ashamed somehow because nobody had changed at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It seemed to make suckers out of so many guys.  And I-I felt wrong to be alive; to to open that bank book, to to drive that car, the new car, and look at that new refrigerator. I mean,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you can take those things out of the war, but if you're gonna drive that car you've got to know that that came from the love a man can have from a man. And you've got to be a little bit better because of that.  Because if you're not, then it's all just loot and there's blood on it and I didn't want any of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you can't feel like that anymore, Chris.  Because everything you have, you have a right to, me included.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you father, he put hundreds of planes in the air and you should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Annie,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] What will I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie I am going to make you a fortune.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?  Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?  I was the first one up.  He was still in bed.  How could he have seen it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, like, four o'clock this morning.  I heard a crack, and I woke up, and I looked out the window and he was standing right there when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, but after it broke he ran back inside and started crying in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured it was best to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear him right through the floor in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out there at that hour?  He's getting just like after Larry died, walking around at night.  He dreams.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it, but you know one thing Mom, we made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  It's the kind of thing that pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know it.  So why do we go on letting him think that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him.  But it's time he knows that nobody else thinks that Larry's alive anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why should he dream about him, walking around looking for him at night?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore, that we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We have to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: how are you gonna prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For Gods sake!  Three years!  Nobody comes back after three years.  That's insane!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.  Now you can talk yourself until you're blue in the face, Chris, but there's no body and there's no grave.  So where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is the God damn newspapers.  I mean every every week a kid turns up, missing like longer than Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right, mom.  Just listen.  You know why I invited Annie her, don't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I have an idea.  But what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to make- to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's okay then?  I should just go ahead and do it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, so it isn't just my business?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You infuriate me sometimes.  Do you know that?  God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Isn't it your business, too, if dad -- if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it?  I mean, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore.  I mean, the girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She is not Larry's girl!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view he's not dead and she's still his girl.  Now, you can go on from there if you know where to go, Chris, but I don't know.  So what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but everytime I reach out for something I- that I want, I have to pull back because I might hurt somebody else.  My whole bloody life; time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you're a considerate fella, there's nothing wrong in that

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that!

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this taken care of first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what if she feels like your father?  And how do you know she will marry you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if that's the case, then that's the end of it.  But from her letters it sounds like she has forgotten him.  I'll find out.  And then we'll thrash it out with dad, all right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, the trouble is you never saw enough women.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's a good reason.  But that doesn't mean anything at all.  I mean, you haven't seen her in five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know her best, all right?  I don't know.  I grew up next to her.  When I think of somebody for my wife these days, I think of Annie.  What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I don't want a -- look, your father thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl and you're pronouncing him dead.  Now, what's going to happen to your father; do you know?  Because, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then, mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  I hoped that if I'd waited, dad would have forgotten about it by now.  And we could have like a normal wedding and everybody happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if that can't happen, I'll just have to get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll go get married and live someplace else.  I don't know, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have been a good son for too long.  A good sucker.  I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  You mean?  Tell me something, you mean that you would leave the business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But don't think like that.  Because what the hell did we work for, Chris?  I mean, this whole thing, it's all for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that, mom.  Just, you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think that way.  Do you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hi. Um-  My luggage didn't come out of the conveyor thingy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm. Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, um, what do I do?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long ago was that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh- Like, an hour and a half ago.  I talked to somebody who was standing out there and they said wait.  Sometimes like random butt- pieces come out late.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh-Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And so I waited there, but nothing came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, okay.  Well, you can fly- file a claim.  Where were you coming from?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was coming from um the Midwest, like Iowa.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So, within the country, though? umm

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know I was in the country.  I mean, it's not that complicated.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, well the chances of it being lost forever, you know, are slight because -- -- you were in the --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I would hope so.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, you know that happens pretty often that sometimes baggage -- -- gets lost.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: People lose --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: forever?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, this is actually, I mean it's -- it's a really important piece of luggage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, it's not big or anything like that.  I mean, it's not worth a lot of money or anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you have insurance on your flight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I mean, don't you get insurance when you buy your ticket or something?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, you have to buy it now.  It's like thirty dollar extra.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, no one even told me about that.  Like, why would I think to buy insurance?  I was- It's like a three hour flight.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: well, it's something that worth

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How can you lose my luggage like from like, in --

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chances are it's probably just you know -- taking time being um- unloaded from the airplane.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -- four hundred miles?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I should hope so.  You know, I need that today.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, well, there's not much I can do.  I can, you can file this report and we'll call you when it comes in.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let me explain to you what the problem is.  My grandfather's remains are in that bag.  And I have to, like, distribute them today.  We're suppose to, you know, throw them out to the sea today.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: wow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Wow.  Well, that's really important, obviously.  But, um --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I mean, if you have a suggestion, like, it would be great to help me out here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh- Actually, I don't know that that's legal. Um- it is the issue

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I don't care if it's legal.  It's happened.  It's already done.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah I mean, Your bag might have been confiscated because it's --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, could you tell me if it's been confiscated then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -- it's a biohazard. so- um

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, some information here would be great.  Some help.  Can you, like, type something in and find out?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Let me just call security.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That would be great.  Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Okay.  Hold on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up; he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Four o clock this morning.  I heard a crack and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right over there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four o clock in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming of him again, walking around.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What he's going to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here at four this morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up and he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was out here at four this morning I heard a crack and I looked out the window and he was standing right over there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But he went back in the kitchen and he cried.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured I'd just let it wait.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I could hear him crying through the floorboards in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is he doing out here at that hour?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming about him again, walking the streets.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know we've made terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, these kinds of things, man they always come back at you.  And this is definitely coming back to us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean a mistake?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just--why shouldn't he walk the nights waiting for him, huh?  Do we contradict him do we say we don't have any hope any more that he's not coming back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him, it's just for God's sake it's time he realized that no one believes with him any more.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What, can you prove it?  What proof do you have?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years. It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is.  But to your father?  You can talk yourself 'til you're blue in the face but there's was no grave and there is no body.  So where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, all right.  Mom, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is those god damn news papers.  Every month some boy comes back missing longer then Larry so--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, okay all right, all right.  Listen, um, you know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I've got an idea but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do?  You're old enough known your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's okay then?  I'm just going to go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You want to make sure that your father's not going to...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See.  Then it's not just my business. Sometimes you infuriate me, you know that?  You know it's just your business too if I tell father and he throws a fit about it, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.  I ignore what I've got to ignore. That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She is not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of view he is not dead and you have no right to take his girl.  I'm just saying that you can go on from there if you know where to go but I'm saying I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is you know every time I reach out for something I have to pull back 'cause I'm afraid it's going to hurt somebody.  All my life...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I wanted to get this all sorted out first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it.  However from her letters I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm just--I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it I think of her, I grew up next to her.  She is what I think of when I think of a wife.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what that'll do to you, to your father, do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it lots of thought.  And I keep coming back to the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: When I think of a family, when I think of my future I see Annie in the center of that and you know and if that can't happen here then I'll go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll leave.  I'll get married and move somewhere else maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  I said what the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, must you be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes I like it for one hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long when I come home I want it nice, I want a family, I want to kids and Annie is in the center of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If that can't happen here...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me you would leave the business for this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right but you don't think like that because what the hell is this all for.  This is all for you, what are we working for Chris? The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm just-- yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just kind of feel numb, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's happened?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You didn't even hear?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Umm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God I've told this story so many times. Umm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't have to if you don't want to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just...I just basically lost someone that was really close to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I've kind of been dealing with all of the...the stuff, you know the hospital and people work because...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He kind of didn't have anyone to take care of that for him, so--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've been taking care of it all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just really...really messed up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He sick for awhile?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just like it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Was it an accident?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I mean it just came on really quick, you know I mean it was a [GARBAGE] it was a sickness but it just --

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: how was sick?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm confused.  He was sick or it was an accident?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was sick. He got sick. He got sick but it happened really, really fast, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. Really fast? Oh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was kind of like boom... done

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just really weird because he was really young you know and it kind of like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: --it just kind of freaks you out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Totally, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So weird you know that like one days it's like you know sounds so stupid but like one day someone's here. And like next day you know they're not here and it just kind of makes you like think about like life and mortality and like that kind of stuff.  You just like used to take for granted--you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Lock

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The plans you make [GARBAGE].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Exactly, you know, and like he had so many plans and he was going to do...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It leaves a hole for you too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so many things, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It leaves a hole for you too, in your plans together.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gets better.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was a really, really good guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A lot of people loved him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: MMhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, it's like affecting a lot of people it's not just me, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long did you know each other?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Umm...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For like eight years.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's good that you were there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm glad I was there. Glad I- glad I got to be there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So weird,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: like I can't...it's like you know it's like "pinch me" it's like I can't believe like I'm dealing with this, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are there things you wish you'd done differently?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Have you tried, uh, Craig's List?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh, what?  Craig's List?  Oh the internet thing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  Isn't that-- that's all like escort services and things like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  There's regular jobs on there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I mean I've been looking for so long that I just figured that--  I mean, I think things like Monster are a lot more reliable than just some random free board.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just saying I have a friend that got a good job on it so I was just recommending it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What kind of a job?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He's like a manager for a theatre.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He's like a house manager. Yeah.  It's a good job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you know what?  I heard about that job.  I applied for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I saw a posting at the theatre.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He got it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You've been looking for a job for a long time; that was a long time ago.  Right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What did he do?  What was so great?  I don't understand why they would pick him over me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  He had a really good resume I guess and--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A resume?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Do you have a resume?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's kind of helpful when getting a job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just- I mean I call people up and I tell them what I'm good at.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe we should sit down some time and you can just tell me all the stuff that you have done and I'll write it out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't like- I don't like sending things in the mail.  I don't want my information out there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You can- or you can just bring it in person.  But they need, generally, something to see, you know, what kind of what that you've done, what kind of--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm there in front of them.  I'm telling them what I'm good at.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But the piece of paper helps, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?  It's a piece of paper.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  But it has an outline, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't want this paper trail, you know.  I just don't want things following me around, like-.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Okay.  Well, um. Maybe--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's just-- You know, I've had this problem before.  You're not the first person to tell me that I need a resume but...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, yeah.  I would imagine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ..I just-..I just think it's kind of prejudiced and they are really discriminating against people who just aren't that way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, sometimes you have to do things that you don't necessarily like to do to have a job. But the job affords you money, you won't have to be taking the bus right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's baloney, that's baloney.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: maybe get a car.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just, you know, think you should try a little harder maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you think that you're better than me because I don't have a car?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, you're riding the bus, too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am riding the bus, but by choice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?  What choice?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To save the environment, carpool.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're saving the environment. mmhmm

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  One less car at a time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Interesting.  That's fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, you don't have to take out your frustration on me, you know, just because...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not frustrated.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...you can't get a job and refuse to have a resume.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who do you think you are?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't think I'm anyone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are so high and mighty.  I just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I- I-I didn't-- okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I'm saving the environment. I'm riding this car because I- I want to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? Oh.  So now you're...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The bus, I'm riding the bus because I want to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you know what?  You don't have to take your anger and your hurt out on me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can not-- you are not here by choice.  Nobody would ride this bus by choice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, Joy come in here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's happening?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got a letter I have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: First thing tomorrow morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand, I don't underst--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How can they do that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They can do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They said you're home for at least four years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess they can do it,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The National Guard is I guess really spread thin and then everyone has to go.  We all have to go back, my whole companies going back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't believe it. I just got back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So yeah, we leave tomorrow...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...we're all shipping out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got I feel like I'm in shock actually.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't even know what to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about the birthday party?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you're just going to have to have it without me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey listen, it's going to be okay though, all right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're going to be fine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Me?  I'm not worried about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to be fine too, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know I have a good... I have a really good group of guys with me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to be okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're going with the same ones?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do promise me you're going to take a lot of pictures.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Always, I always do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not the same though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just wish there was something I could do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We could hide away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Run away?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mm hmm.  We'll build a bunker and never come out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I really don't want to go, I don't want to go...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Mmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm scared.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll send you a letter every single day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I love you too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However, I do believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents? It was a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all. It was very pretty. I still wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You sent out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did not you worked whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot, a great deal of pleasure and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you'd never known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I.  I'm bored stiff.  You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want any you already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you know no particular reason besides they are very small glasses.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just think it's silly you know to go on and on and on about such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three glasses of liquor in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I just think it's becoming a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.  Well, you needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any at the moment, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid, what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, darling I'm just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it's a woman's duty to allure the man. Watch me a minute will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As matter the fact that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh no, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid, shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, it's a pity you didn't have any more brandy. It would have made you just a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, well that's funny.  It doesn't seem to have worked such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what?  You snap, you snap, you snap you're like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a bag of venom behind of fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care.  I don't care, do you understand?  I don't mind if they bark and they roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you let him just kiss you or good deal more than too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, mind you own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you two had a riotous time, huh?  No restrain at all, very enjoyable, he never had much any how.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable, I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I told you once before that I had three minute liquor glasses the whole evening long.  A Child of two cannot get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child two could get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh very, very interesting Amanda.  How about the child of uh... four, six or maybe nine---you know, we could work up a splendid little debate about it, you know?  Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny darling.  Why don't you have some more brandy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a very good idea I think I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Would you uh...turn that off please? You're going to wake the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There are no people upstairs. It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then you'll wake the people downstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They are away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time a year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off. It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. No. Go away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda listen. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: listen Oh I'm sick and tired of listening to you, you damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you're cruel you're...you're...I hate you, I hate you. Go away. You're conceited. You're overbearing. You're utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You...You're an evil minded, self-centered little wench and I never want to see you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end do you hear me?  Finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yes I am...Oh yes I am. Let go of me. You let go. You...urgh...You're a cruel friend. I loathe and I hate you. Marry you again...Ha...Never, never, never, never. I hope you die in torment. You beast.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up. I wouldn't marry you again if you came crawling back to me on a bended knee. You are an evil tempered little vampire and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say, maybe we ought to tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it? I was the first one up he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four this morning. I heard it cracking and I woke up and looked out. He was standing right here when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. When it cracked he ran into the house and cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So you talked to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I figured it was best to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear him right through the floor in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at that hour? He's dreaming about him again, he's walking around at night.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like after he died. What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it, but I know one thing mom, we've made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him. I mean that sort of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry is not coming back and I know it. Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I don't want to argue with him, but it's about time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why -- why shouldn't he dream of him? Walk around, waiting for him at night I mean do we contradict him, do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore that we haven't had hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can you prove it, how can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God sakes it's been three years, nobody comes back after three years, that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me. You can talk yourself blue in the face but there is no body and no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down mom; I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is the god damned newspapers, every month or so a boy turns up out of nowhere, so the next one is going to be Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Listen to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why I brought Annie here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I got an idea but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do; you're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's all right then I'll go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See it isn't just my business-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sometimes you infuriate me you know that. Isn't it your business to if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it? You have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore. The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of you he isn't dead and you have no right to take his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can go on from there if you know where to go but I don't know where to go, see I don't know. So what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why but every time I reach out for something that I really want, I have to pull back 'cause someone else will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong with that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you know she'll marry you? Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it. From her letters I think she's forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, I'll find out. Then we'll trash it out with dad, right? Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything. I mean you haven't seen her since you went away to war it's five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it I know her best. I mean lived next door to her my whole life. These years when I think of a wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram. He thinks he's coming back. Chris, you marry this girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what's going to happen to your father because I don't, see?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought. I thought that if I waited, dad would forget about Larry and we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If I can't do that here well, then I'll have to get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out. I'll get married and go live some place else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this, are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long a good sucker, I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about the business? What is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I like it and hour a day. If I'm going to grub for money all day long, at least in the evening I want it beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want a family; I want kids; I want something I can give myself to. Annie is in the middle of that. Now where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me, you'd leave the business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right. But you don't want to be thinking like that 'cause otherwise what did we work for, I mean the whole thing is for you, Chris, the whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know I know mom. All right. Just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't go thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I am thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you're never going to believe it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What? What? You look really happy what's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I finally did it

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Finally did what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I asked her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You did? Oh, my Gosh, I'm so proud of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I know. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my Gosh. Well, and did

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm so nervous you know, I'm-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did she say yes?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, she said yes. [LAUGHTER] I know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's like the most definitive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know Uhm- I can't believe it.  It's like-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my gosh, wait so when did you decide to do this, I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would have thought you would have told me that you were planning on doing this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, yes, I wanted it you know I guess sort of as a surprise for everyone so

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, I guess so. Oh, my Gosh. Was she surprised?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. You know, she - she was like - I mean, she was happy, you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I - I think it was about time, I don't know, maybe. You know what, it's been it's been long enough now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So what did you do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, well, it was -- you know, we were at this- at this concert and yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so I-I talked to some of the crew before hand and-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, You did not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my Gosh. that's so cute

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So I got the band to do something, you know, like towards the end of the song I got to go up on stage and, uh

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's so romantic. Oh, my Gosh. She must have died. That's like one of those things you write into a magazine about like my boyfriend did this. Oh my God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, so

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got to freak her out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, yes -- so

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She must have flipped out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, that way she was guaranteed that she could not say no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right exactly because you can't say no in front of thousands of people. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, but it was good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you bring her up on stage too?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, my Gosh, that's so cute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know it was, I don't know I was really nervous but I'm really - I'm really glad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are your parents excited or...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yes, they - they you know they love her and so I mean...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, totally. So when is it going to happen?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, we're thinking uh - we're thinking winter time, you know, we're going to do it in the winter and then maybe, you know, maybe

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know either do a honeymoon like in the snow or fly down to like Australia, Southern Hemisphere, [GARBAGE] so we'll decide with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ooh, that would be fun.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think you'll get a house or something, like you guys are looking to buy some place or

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, yea, I'm not too sure where yet I guess you know, I kind of got to figure some stuff out here first

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: but like you know it's just - I guess we're just excited right now that we'll get to continue it together.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my Gosh. I cannot believe you're getting married, that is so cool.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Golly, it just makes me all like romantic inside, like I really want that to happen to me. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, it will, obviously you know. But I know it's something - I don't know, you never really think about it happening, like before hand.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you have a good ring? You better have had a good ring.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure. Oh, yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Good. The ring makes all the difference.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I had my mom come along maybe help me out a little bit because she's got good taste. but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, that's awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, well, Thanks, thanks. Thank you. yeah

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yay, well congratulations, that's so cool. [BREATHING] I can't wait.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, a what's up?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, Johnny died yesterday.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow, that's horrible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear about that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We knew that it was coming, but--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It seemed like he had a little bit longer.  Like just last week, he was doing was so well.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, you know, at least he's not in anymore pain now, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's good, you know.  you know It hurts I know.  I know what it's like to lose someone like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't want him to be gone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: 'Cause, you know, you've got all the times that you guys did spend together, you know and that's something good that you can look back on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean--I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And his whole family was there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, he was like really conscious right up until the end. you know

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, that's that's good, you know.  At least, I don't know.  I mean it's- it's better to go- to goout that way than...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: .than you know, in pain and like this gradual, this horrible process.  I mean--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He was so young, you know.  And all the stories he used to tell me about...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...the way he wanted to live and he was gonna go to Africa and he was gonna--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But look at the--he--look at the life he did get to lead.  I mean, for his age, he'd done so much and--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody's ever gonna forget him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly.  He's made a big impact on a lot of people. and

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And you'll always have that and--you should feel, you know, happy for him that he got to do so much before--I mean, and even after he found out last year.  I mean--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He did a lot.  But--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It doesn't bring him back, but--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But It's okay because now, you know, you'll just go on with your life and--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm gonna forget him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you'll never forget him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't be able to hear his voice or his--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. but you're not  I mean you're not going to forget him.  The pain will go away eventually and--or it will subside--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You start to lose like that image after a while.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That will be, It'll be--it'll be better that way. I mean Time will tell.  Time heals, you know, and it's good.  It's okay.  I mean, it wasn't anybody's fault or anything like that so .

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's hard to lose someone that way, but he's he's better--he's better off now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. Customer service this is Steve.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hi. Thank you so much, you're a real person, right, you're not like a recording?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm a real person, yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. Before I get into it, um your menu or whatever like where you choose the different thing depending on the-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it leads you around in circles, you can't, there is no way to like get to a real person if you don't already know how to get to there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right. No, yes I know. It is-It is a little frustrating.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So is there any way to like bypass that because that is so, like I've been going around in circles

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like press nine, press zero, press back to the menu, like I can't get through to what I'm supposed to get through to.

dialogue.speaker: M
