dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you have your forms?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let me see them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is there a problem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who told you to get in this line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were standing at the beginning and you directed me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. But I didn't tell you to get in this line if you are filling out this particular form.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what's the problem?  Let me change it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This form is a Z.X.four.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't--  This is not the line for Z.X.four.  If you're going to fill out the Z.X.four, you need to have a different form of ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  I'm getting an ID.  This is why I'm here.  My wallet was stolen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I need another set of ID to prove this is actually you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How am I supposed to get an ID without an ID?  How does a person get an ID in the first place?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I need an ID to pass this form along.  I can't just send it along without an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm here to get an ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I need another ID, a separate one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like what?  Like a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A birth certificate, a passport...a student ID; didn't you go to school?  Anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who the hell has a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes but my wallet was stolen, I don't have anything.  I don't have any credit cards, I don't have my ID.  Don't you have things on file here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  We keep it on file, but we need an ID to access that file.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's out of control.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand why this is so complicated for people when they get here.  It's just a simple form.  I just need an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long have you been working here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually too long.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Clearly.  You know, do you have like a supervisor or something?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Huh? Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Fine.  I'll be right back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That would - I would appreciate that.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and an half years, why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe...maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  You know he lived next door to the girl his whole life, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She is not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men, why is she still single?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my darkest moments, I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey look, it's a nice day, huh?  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith, Joe.  You know strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to-- I want you to act like he is coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since Chris invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  Oh laugh, laugh all you like but why does this happen the very night he comes back.  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just believe with me, Joe. Only last week a man came back in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  Believe with me. You, above all, have got to believe. Just believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you get the mail? So you saw my letter?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand.  You've already done so much, I don't know why do you have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I put in that. request too. They didn't...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess, you know, everybody has to make sacrifices.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it's just not fair.  I think you've already made your sacrifice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's people that have given more though, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just don't see how they can make you leave when you have a new baby - we have a new kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then why is that fair?  Why--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's babies over there, though, that need mothers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how you can be okay with this?  I don't know why you're not-- you're fine with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not okay with it, but I don't-- it's not like I have a choice.  I don't see what crying about it is going to fix.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just trying to think of another way.  I'm just trying to...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, you know, kicking myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like you sign up because you need money and

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: things just aren't what they seem.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a stupid war.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We're doing the right thing, though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If not me then, who?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I going to do? Huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'll videotape everything, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe you can send it to me, like stream it, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't you guys have access to computers over there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last month--  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just don't know how I'm going to do it without you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have to find sitters.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't raise a baby by myself.  How?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We've got friends, that's why we moved here, huh?  Because there is a day care down the street.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And your mother is close by.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll send you lots of letters.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I want lots and lots and lots of pictures.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just not fair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However, I do believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents? It was a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all. It was very pretty. I still wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You sent out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did not you worked whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot, a great deal of pleasure and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you'd never known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I.  I'm bored stiff.  You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want any you already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you know no particular reason besides they are very small glasses.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just think it's silly you know to go on and on and on about such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three glasses of liquor in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I just think it's becoming a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.  Well, you needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any at the moment, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid, what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, darling I'm just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it's a woman's duty to allure the man. Watch me a minute will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As matter the fact that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh no, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid, shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, it's a pity you didn't have any more brandy. It would have made you just a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, well that's funny.  It doesn't seem to have worked such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what?  You snap, you snap, you snap you're like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a bag of venom behind of fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care.  I don't care, do you understand?  I don't mind if they bark and they roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you let him just kiss you or good deal more than too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, mind you own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you two had a riotous time, huh?  No restrain at all, very enjoyable, he never had much any how.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable, I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I told you once before that I had three minute liquor glasses the whole evening long.  A Child of two cannot get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child two could get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh very, very interesting Amanda.  How about the child of uh... four, six or maybe nine---you know, we could work up a splendid little debate about it, you know?  Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny darling.  Why don't you have some more brandy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a very good idea I think I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Would you uh...turn that off please? You're going to wake the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There are no people upstairs. It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then you'll wake the people downstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They are away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time a year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off. It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. No. Go away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda listen. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: listen Oh I'm sick and tired of listening to you, you damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you're cruel you're...you're...I hate you, I hate you. Go away. You're conceited. You're overbearing. You're utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You...You're an evil minded, self-centered little wench and I never want to see you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end do you hear me?  Finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yes I am...Oh yes I am. Let go of me. You let go. You...urgh...You're a cruel friend. I loathe and I hate you. Marry you again...Ha...Never, never, never, never. I hope you die in torment. You beast.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up. I wouldn't marry you again if you came crawling back to me on a bended knee. You are an evil tempered little vampire and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What time is it? They're supposed to run around midnight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, this great, isn't it? Like look at the night we go here, it couldn't be better.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I would have wanted to go a little further up the coast, get away from the lights and the people but I was afraid we'd miss it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is that -- is that, no? Was that just foam? I can't even tell.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Although, I guess you can't tell it probably isn't them. Probably be unmistakable don't you think?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How you doing? You know what I forgot? I forgot to bring my flashlight. How - how could I forget to bring my flashlight? How could I be so stupid?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What flashlight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know the flashlight, the silver one, there is only one, isn't there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not your flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who's is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ours; it's mine too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh well, sure, yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But you kept saying my flashlight as if somehow it's just yours. I mean how is it supposed to make me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No. Of course our flashlight yours and mine. Mi flashlight, es su flashlight, naturally.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How could we forget to bring it?  I hope the moon stays out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder do they always run during a full moon? I can't remember if it was full last year, do you remember?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You cold, you want my jacket? We should've - we should've brought our blanket, our blanket, how could we forget to bring the blanket?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, a six-pack, that's, should've brought a -- a six-pack be just the ticket right now. How could I forget,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: oh man. Like a kid, it's amazing I got out of the house with my fly zipped.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think they can hear us talk or feel the vibrations in the sand when we move around?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm cold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What you want my jacket?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's after eleven. Let's just go home.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you kidding, we'd miss it. We, we just got here. What's the point in coming down here if we just turn around and go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There is no point in coming down here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's my point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's my point too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No. That's not my point. The point is there is no point in coming down here if we just leave. Don't you want to see it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not particularly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't, it's just stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey, this is a natural phenomenon. I mean it only happens once a year.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Think about the people in Kansas, they- they'd have to get a plane ticket and hotel reservations to see this. We live forty minutes away it's too good to pass up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pass up what? These little fish swim onto the beach flop around and swim away, and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yea, but that moment on the beach is the highlight of their little lives. I mean all that flopping is laying eggs or what do you, mating or spotting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a big night for these guys, life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you so excited about? I mean it's not a moon landing we're talking about here it's fish. It's a fish nobody even eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. But it's fish that do something none of the other fish do. Like the swallows returning to Capistrano, or the Lemmings throwing themselves off the cliffs

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you know there is like, there is a certain mystery here, a magic, a bit of the unexplainable. I don't see how you cannot be interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't get it. The first time we came here you said it was the best night of your life.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then last year I remember specifically you were so excited that you stubbed your toe on the way pushing me out of the house, and you didn't even notice until we got in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last year you'll also remember our shoes got wet, I got sand in my panties, you got a sore throat, we got into a big fight over nothing, and we didn't see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We weren't in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We didn't see them the first time either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot; this is a much better spot. I've got good instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There is that, oh no that's just seaweed, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is, this is great, isn't it? I wouldn't miss this for anything. Now listen to this, I know you're not interested but just listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Out there somewhere there is this huge mass of silver fish headed this way,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: they don't why, we don't know why. They didn't take a vote or anything; they didn't get a map or an invitation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just all as one. This little time sensitive firecracker, instinctual firecracker in their body just went off and all as one they turned and formed a line as long the California coast and started swimming. They're swimming right now as if that's the only thing that matters.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness, with no mind, it's urgency that's pure urge, they don't know what drives them. They don't ask it a name or ask it a question,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: they just turn as one and start the swim and brings them right here to this spot where we stand, for a massive celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at me; I'm giving myself goose bumps all my hairs are popping up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I was saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hi, um, excuse me, I believe that the airline lost my baggage.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um, okay, it didn't--didn't come out on the carrousel--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it didn't. um It didn't come out and I don't see it anywhere around here, so what can you do about that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Um, well, unfortunately yeah there was a some- some problems with the--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Some problems?  What is that supposed to mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh, well some-some of the bags were--were lost on the way over here. uh-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you lose a suitcase?  A huge suitcase?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, I mean, there's a lot of things that go on under the plane and sometimes, you know, that kind of things happen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh, But, we are willing to reimburse you for the bag and and for the contents--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How much?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um, we'd be willing to give you uh fifty dollars for--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fifty dollars?  For my suitcase?  I mean, the suitcase itself was like a hundred and fifty dollar just for the suitcase, but all the things inside, all my clothes, all my personal belongings, the sentimental value, not to mention, which is more-more than all of that together.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.  Uh We realize, you know, that that it's a bad situation, but I'm sorry, there's nothing that we can really do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's all, that's all, that's all you're going to do is just give me fifty dollars and say go have fun on your vacation without any of your stuff?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think, um, maybe you can file a claim if you want and turn it in to our main office--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, I would like to file a claim, but what are you gonna--I mean, is it just gonna show up magically out of nowhere?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.  No.  I mean they- they might--they might--if you-if you are argue the case more, maybe they'll reimburse you more, but, right now--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need my stuff.  It's--I need my stuff.  I mean, uh...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Haven't you ever lost baggage?  I mean isn't there anything else you do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I know. I know-. It's It's frustrating.  Unfortunately though-- um

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you don't seem to care very much, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: By checking your bags, you--you, you know- admit to the liability that's- that's at risk--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't sign anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right, well, by checking in your bags, you agreed to, you know, at the will of the--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't agree.  [GARBAGE] I paid the airline to take care of things for me.  When you pay for something, there should be some sort of guarantee that it's gonna come through.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You paid for the flight and then your bags were checked at--it's a service that the airline provides for us.  So so, really, it's really the risk was taken and, I'm sorry, but there's really nothing else we can do.  So do you want--do you want the reimbursement?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Well, sure, yeah, I guess I'll go buy dinner and then be--have nothing for the rest of my entire vacation.  I'm supposed to be here for three weeks.  What am I gonna do without anything for three weeks?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, there are-there are some shops here in- in the airport--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But fifty dollars isn't going to get me anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, um, like I said you can file a claim and, uh, maybe get reimbursed for more-- you

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Isn't there anything else you can do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: probably even talk to--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, is there somebody you can call?  Or the guy that put the stuff on the--on the plane.  I mean, are they--they must be really irresponsible to have just disappeared my baggage.  I mean, did it get stolen?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right, that--that gets taken care of-- That gets taken care of.  We get we do, you know, we investigate those and just make sure that um- they're not doing their own thing with them so--uh

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm sure you -- You're like, hmm, do you take baggage?  No.  Oh, okay, thanks.  Great.  I mean how--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: but Unfortunately sometimes is--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, that's--that's what I'm saying--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There needs to be better security here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Well that that could be something that you put on on the claim--on on the complaint form if you want.  And provide us with your information while you're here and then, maybe, if it turns up, then we'll send it right over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It sounds like it's such a little like oh well no big deal whatever.  It's a big deal to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, Miss, I-I know.  I realize this. But Like I said, there are several people that are in your same situation, so, um, it's not--it's not totally uncommon and I'm actually gonna have to ask you to move so I can help the next person.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, can I at least have my fifty dollars, please?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, all right.  There you go, now you can file a claim over to the left--And they'll help you out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hi, my name is Shiloh, welcome to--Airline Six.  Hi, how may I help you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, hello.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ok.  I've- I've just been talking to this machine for the past half hour and I can't-can't get anything done.  I've been trying to book this vacation this entire time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right, sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I'm sorry.  It's-It's just that it's been a little frustrating because--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I completely understand.  Automated systems are very difficult sometimes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Anne.  Give me a-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I kissed Annie.  How long--how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  I mean, all I did was sit and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Annie, we're gonna live now.  I'm gonna make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive someplace.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  What is it, Chris. Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what's wrong?  I mean, even in your letters there was some--something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've gotta tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in charge of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: gee.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes some time for a guy to toss that off.  'Cause they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, this one time, it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.  I put them in pocket.  It's only a little thing, but those are the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  I mean, a little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got this idea watching 'em go down.  Everything was being destroyed, see, but it seemed that one new thing was made.  A sort of responsibility.  Man for man. You know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To show that, to bring that onto the Earth again, like some kind of monument and everyone can feel it standing behind him and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I came back and it was incredible.  There was no meaning in it here. I mean, the whole thing to them seemed like it's sort of a bus accident.  I went to work with Dad and that rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt what you said, ashamed somehow 'cause nobody had changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive to open the new bank book, drive the new car, see the new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, you can take those things out of a war, but when you drive that car, you've gotta realize that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've gotta be a little better because of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise all you have is really loot and there's blood on it.  And I didn't want to take any of that.  And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause you mustn't feel that way.  Because you have a right to everything you have, Chris.  Everything, you understand that?  Me too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, and your money, there's- there's nothing wrong with your money.  I mean, your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know Annie.  I'm gonna make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents, just a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I remember it well, bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it wasn't. It was very pretty I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I didn't, you worked the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you; you said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot of pleasure, it didn't hurt me any.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so nosey and suspicious you never wouldn't have known anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored of this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, me too, bored stiff. You want some Brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have a little I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want any you've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason. Anyhow, they are very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It just seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because don't happen want any yourself right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I'm just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a woman's job to allure the man

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, no it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have any more Brandy it might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It doesn't seem to work such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh nonsense they have a little bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. Do you understand? I don't care. I don't care if they bark or roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Tell me, did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine you let him kiss you good deal more then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What riotous time you must have had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No restraint at all, very enjoyable, never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable. I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not in the least drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine, as I may have already mentioned, I've had three minute liquor glasses of Brandy the whole evening long a child of two couldn't get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary a child of two could get violently drunk on only one glass of Brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh very interesting. How about a child of four, a child of six or a child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can get a good little debate going about that, don't you think? Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny my dear, you better have some more Brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Better turn that off I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it's late and it'll annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs it's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are people downstairs I suppose?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well, if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off it's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental. Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. Stop it. I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen indeed. I'm sick and tired of listening to you, damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. Stop it. I hate you, do you hear? You're overbearing and conceited and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a vile tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I hope I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end, do you hear? The end finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I am. Let go of me you're cruel fiend and I hate and loathe you. Thank God I realized who you really are before I would ever, ever marry you again. I would never marry you again. I'd rather die in torment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you again if you came to me on your bended knees. You're a evil minded little vampire. I hope to God I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a beast. I hate you. Stop it. Stop it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can I help you sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been here for four hours and I don't know where one piece of my luggage is

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Well let's...well I'm going to go ahead and check on that for you.  You're coming from...where are you coming from?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Baltimore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Baltimore and this is a direct flight to LAX

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Let's look up here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know and they've looked it up before and it's not there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Well you um-...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now what are you going to do for me different? Hmm?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What I can do for you is uh we can uh report lost, lost property.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can report lost property?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm leaving LA tomorrow for San Diego, driving there.  So, I'm going to leave without all my lost property?  That's what you want me to do? um

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sir, if if...what I believe has happened is most of the flight was left--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: the luggage was left in Baltimore.  Therefore--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Most of the...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like the luggage, the luggage on the flight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow.  This is an incompetent airline isn't it?  Are you--?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No actually it was...this is the first time this has ever happened.  I don't know what happened--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you going to refund us for our luggage, refund us for our tickets for this?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We- I mean-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, we can give you um- hotel lodging for a night if that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to San Diego tomorrow to stay with my family.  What do I need hotel lodging for hmmm?  Can you tell me that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For tonight- For tonight sir.  Would you need to stay somewhere tonight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Tonight no.  I'm driving tomorrow.  Tonight I'm staying with a friend alright?  I don't need hotel reservations...where?  What hotel?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can do Holiday Inn or...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow.  Thank you.  Holiday Inn.  Wow.  Thank...the flight cost five hundred dollars.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir I understand that but just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, so you can put me in Holiday Inn for twenty dollar a night?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you have your name tags on the luggage?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course I had my name tags on the luggage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  So if you can just give me your name, your name and your address and your phone number I can contact you as soon as we find out more information.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Soon as you...that's not good enough okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, please calm down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I need you to help me out here.  Can you get on the phone and get the luggage over on the fastest flight you can and then maybe I won't get you fired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If not, I'm going to get your name, I'm going to talk to your boss, whoever...I'm never going to fly...my business is never going to fly Delta again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is your business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I work for IBM.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Sir?  I am sorry to tell you this but this does happen. Uh- This is not uh- really,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, our airline's fault.  I don't know what happened, misplaced, something happened but we will get you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You misplace a lot of, eight pieces of luggage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, the entire flight, sir, the luggage was placed on another plane that never actually left Baltimore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh no I'm not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who are you going to fire because of that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well we have some people back there that need some firing so, but I would just really appreciate--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow.  This has never happened before.  I've not lost,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: in all thousand flights I've been on probably I can't even count how many flights I've been on.  This has never happened before.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is the worst customer service I've ever gotten before.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay sir.  I'm sorry you can--um-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Get on the phone and figure out where my luggage is and tell me when it's going to get there alright?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We already have been confirmed that it will be arriving in--uh--in about two days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And and, in about...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Two days I'll be in San Diego and how's it going to get to me in San Diego?  You going to make sure it gets to the San Diego airport?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh, we can't--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Can you get it to the San Diego airport?  You get someone to drive it to my place alright? Then I get a refund for some...I get a free flight alright? I get free whatever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes sir, Yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can have them direct your luggage to San Diego.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  And you're going to give me what for my inconvenience?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Some refreshments in the lobby?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Some peanuts?  Wow.  That helps a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thanks you, thank you I don't have my luggage so you gave me a Holiday Inn stay and peanuts.  Wow.  You know what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: eh- we actually--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will never do business with Delta again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on man?  What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just so tired all the time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well have you been trying to get a job, look for a job or...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been looking for like eight months.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  It- It's really tough out there.  It's really hard to find a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm tired of the same excuses.  No, no you're not qualified enough, wish you had more education.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what are you looking for?  I mean--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Last time someone told me I was too qualified.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, okay. Well that's--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Cause I went to Harvard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's what?  For what job?  Who...what jobs are you looking for?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I applied as restaurant manager at P.F. Chang.  I applied at----Macy's store manager. Tried to get investment banking job with Deloitte and Touche.  I'm trying everywhere.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, Listen--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Well it seems to me, you know, you just got to keep going out there, you know, pushing through.  You got a Harvard degree.  I mean, you can get a job anywhere.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what?  I've been working at temp jobs for the past six months.  You know how degrading it is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To be a receptionist?  Oh I spent forty thousand dollar a year for my college degree and I'm a receptionist.  God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm smarter than half the people I work for.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you...what would ideally like to do, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know astronaut?  I don't know something crazy like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what'd you major in?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Biomedical Engineering.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You-You can't be working as a restaurant manager, I mean, come on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to do engineering though.  It's so...I had the internship what, last summer,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and I was pulling my hair out and it was like, oh my God.  So I just had to finish the major so now they're like, why are you an engineering major, and why are you working, trying to work at a restaurant.  And it's like I don't know just give me the damn job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look I'm sorry-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why all these questions?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know if you need any help finding a place I can, I can talk to my work you know I work at that law firm downtown and I can ask if they're looking for anybody.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yeah?  What kind of jobs they got?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am...just like a law clerk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to be a law clerk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm moving up.  I mean it could be...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To be a lawyer?  You go to law school now?  God this is, all these dead ends.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And plus my car is breaking down-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -they're evicting me from my apartment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it doesn't make any sense though.  Like, with a Harvard degree you should be able to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know.  You'd think I would be able to be C.E.O. of a company right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, you got to hang in there.  Can you ask your parents for help or anybody?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I'm not going to...yeah, they'd laugh in my face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just for a little bit, you know?  Cause I-I guarantee you're going to find something.  When you find something it's just going to be huge and you're going to get money.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I got a sixteen hundred on my S.A.T..

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Something-- How are you going...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm freaking----typing sixty words a minute.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many words a minute?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sixty words.  Sixty words a minute.  Hey how are you doing Mr. Smith?  Oh, you know, it's just like God, I just want to shoot you Mr. Smith.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sixty words a minute.  That's a min...a word per min uh second.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  It's alright.  But--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You could be an amazing receptionist.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not cut to be a receptionist.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yeah.  I will be a full time receptionist.  Harvard degree, sixteen hundred on my S.A.T.--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well... If you need something, I mean, you're just going to---can get a temporary thing right now and then look for something--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: --you know? Head of the Science Club.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's what I've been doing, temporary things

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh I know.  But--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -it's going to get better I promise you. You just got to hang in there. Everyone, I mean, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe I'll just kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  You can't...what?  Now come on.  Stop it.  Don't be talking like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was just joking...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: My, what I would do was just, you know, what about can you call Harvard and see...don't they have connections?  Don't they have like career center and you can find some stuff that's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I--they said Brian you're too smart.  You don't need us.

dialogue.speaker: M
